user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_BSP_EndTest:
```c
void UT_BSP_EndTest(const UtAssert_TestCounter_t *TestCounters)
{
    char Message[128];

    /*
     * Only output a "summary" if there is more than one test Segment.
     * Otherwise it is a duplicate of the report already given.
     */
    if (TestCounters->TestSegmentCount > 1)
    {
        UtAssert_DoTestSegmentReport("SUMMARY", TestCounters);
    }

    snprintf(Message, sizeof(Message), "COMPLETE: %u tests Segment(s) executed\n\n",
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->TestSegmentCount);

    UT_BSP_Lock();
    OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(Message, strlen(Message));
    UT_BSP_Unlock();

    if ((TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FAILURE] > 0) ||
        (TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TSF] > 0) || (TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TTF] > 0))
    {
        OS_BSP_SetExitCode(OS_ERROR);
    }
    else
    {
        OS_BSP_SetExitCode(OS_SUCCESS);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UT_BSP_EndTest:
typedef struct
{
    uint32 TestSegmentCount;
    uint32 TotalTestCases;
    uint32 CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_MAX];
} UtAssert_TestCounter_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The function parameter TestCounters is already declared as a pointer to const (const UtAssert_TestCounter_t *), so usages that only read from it (e.g. TestCounters->TestSegmentCount and indexing CaseCount[]) do not need further investigation. The local array Message is used as an output buffer (written by snprintf), so it must be a non-const char[] and that use is appropriate. Calls to snprintf and strlen use standard library prototypes that already take const where appropriate (snprintf writes to Message, so its destination cannot be const; the format argument is const). UT_BSP_Lock/Unlock and OS_BSP_SetExitCode do not involve pointer parameters and thus are not relevant to Rule 8.13. The two listed calls are flagged because they pass pointer arguments (a string literal and the Message buffer / TestCounters pointer) to external functions whose parameter declarations are not shown here; those callee parameter types should be checked to ensure they accept const-qualified pointers where possible (e.g. const char * or const UtAssert_TestCounter_t *).
